TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit UIPropertyMetadata extends System.Windows.PropertyMetadata

Docs.summary: Provides property metadata for non-framework properties that do have rendering/user interface impact at the core level.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkPropertyMetadata> (derived from this class) is the more common metadata class used for framework-level properties that also have rendering/user interface impact.

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(object defaultValue) cil managed

Docs.param: The default value of the dependency property, usually provided as a value of some specific type.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, with the specified default value for the property.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class System.Windows.PropertyChangedCallback propertyChangedCallback) cil managed

Docs.param: Reference to a handler implementation that is to be called by the property system whenever the effective value of the property changes.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, with the specified PropertyChanged callback.

Reference to a handler implementation that is to be called by the property system whenever the effective value of the property changes.
Reference to a handler implementation that is to be called whenever the property system calls against this property.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, with the specified default value and callbacks.

MemberSignature.Value: public UIPropertyMetadata (object defaultValue, System.Windows.PropertyChangedCallback propertyChangedCallback, System.Windows.CoerceValueCallback coerceValueCallback, bool isAnimationProhibited);

.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(object defaultValue, class System.Windows.PropertyChangedCallback propertyChangedCallback, class System.Windows.CoerceValueCallback coerceValueCallback, bool isAnimationProhibited) cil managed

Docs.param: The default value of the dependency property, usually provided as a value of some specific type.
Reference to a handler implementation that is to be called by the property system whenever the effective value of the property changes.
Reference to a handler implementation that is to be called whenever the property system calls against this property.

Set to to prevent the property system from animating the property that this metadata is applied to. Such properties will raise run time exceptions if animations of them are attempted. The default is .
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, with the specified default value and callbacks, and a Boolean used to disable animations on the property.
Gets or sets a value declaring whether animations should be disabled on the dependency property where the containing metadata instance is applied.
Docs.value: indicates that animations are disallowed; indicates that animations are allowed. The default is (animations allowed).

remarks.format:
## Remarks In general, the default dependency properties available in the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_winclient](~/includes/tlasharptla-winclient-md.md)] framework implementation [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_api#plural](~/includes/tlasharptla-apisharpplural-md.md)] can be animated. You might set this property to `true` in the metadata of your own custom dependency property to disable animations on it.
If a property with this value `true` attempts to be used as an animation target, a runtime exception will be raised.
Properties on any derived classes of <xref:System.Windows.PropertyMetadata> are normally defined in the object model as read-write. This is so they can be adjusted after initialization of the instance. However, once the metadata is consumed as part of a call to <xref:System.Windows.DependencyProperty.Register%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.DependencyProperty.AddOwner%2A>, or <xref:System.Windows.DependencyProperty.OverrideMetadata%2A>, the property system will seal that metadata instance and any properties that convey the specifics of the metadata are now considered immutable. Attempting to set <xref:System.Windows.UIPropertyMetadata.IsAnimationProhibited%2A> once <xref:System.Windows.PropertyMetadata.IsSealed%2A> is `true` on this metadata instance will raise an exception.
